Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as the shrill site alarm pierced the air. I glanced at the screen—Sam, an old friend I hadn’t seen in months, was calling. I answered, and his voice was shaky. “My car broke down on the old Mill Road. Can you come? There’s no one else nearby.” I looked around; my crew was already dropping tools, heading for the muster point as the evacuation protocol demanded. My supervisor’s voice echoed, “No exceptions—everyone out, now!” I felt the weight of my hard hat pressing down, sweat prickling my neck. Sam’s voice was desperate, and I knew he’d helped me before. But the rules here were strict—leaving the muster point or even lagging behind could mean disciplinary action, or worse, put someone in danger. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the urgent call of a friend stranded and the blaring alarm demanding my presence with my team.
